Headline: Country music legend: Kenny Rogers
Article_Body: Kenny Rogers poses with his guitar in the backyard of his Brentwood, California, home in 1978. Kenny Rogers, Thelma Camacho, Mike Settle and Terry Williams of the band "Kenny Rogers & The First Edition" pose for a portrait session in 1967. Rogers records in a studio in Los Angeles in 1968. Rogers performs with the First Edition in 1970. Rogers poses for a photo on his wedding day in 1977. From left: John Davidson, Glen Campbell, bride Marianne Gordon, Rogers and John Denver. Rogers speaks to a group of journalists in London in 1977. Rogers and Dottie West appear at the CMA Awards in Nashville in 1978. Rogers holds his Grammy award for best male country performer in 1980. Rogers performs in 1980. Rogers poses for a photo with members of the cast of the film "Six Pack" in 1982. Rogers and son Christopher Cody Rogers attend the American Music Awards in 1983. Rogers has his hands full as he balances his 13-month-old son Christopher backstage during the American Music Awards in 1983. Dolly Parton and Rogers rehearse a song for their appearance on the TV show "Live... And in Person" in 1983. Rogers, national co-chairman of Hands Across America, gestures while addressing a sign up rally for the group in 1986. From left: Burt Bacharach, Carole Bayer Sager and Rogers record music for the film "Tough Guys" in 1986. Rogers opens an exhibit of his photographs in 1986. Rogers and Dolly Parton perform in 1990. Rogers sings behind President Bill Clinton as they perform at the DC Armory Ball during Clinton's inauguration festivities in 1993. Rogers talks with "Tonight Show" host Jay Leno in 1994 as Charles Barkley looks on. Rogers performs in London in 2009. Rogers gives an autograph to musician Aden Bubeck backstage during the ACM Honors in Nashville in 2009. From left: Alison Krauss, Rogers and Billy Dean perform at the MGM Grand at Foxwoods in Connecticut in 2010. Rogers and Trey Anastasio of Phish perform at Bonnaroo in 2012. Joe Bonsall and Rogers pose as Rogers is inducted into the Nashville Music City Walk of Fame on in 2017. Rogers and Dolly Parton share a few stories at "All In For The Gambler: Kenny Rogers' Farewell Concert Celebration" in 2017.
